prompt: Moral dilemmas pose what challenge to standard deontic logic?
options: They suggest O(p) and O(¬p) might both hold
They prove ethics cannot be formalized
hint: Sometimes we seem obligated to do incompatible things.
explanation: Moral dilemmas suggest conflicting obligations: O(p) ∧ O(¬p). Sartre's student: obligated to stay with mother AND join resistance. Standard deontic logic often makes this inconsistent. Some argue for dilemma-tolerant deontic logics that accept genuine conflicts.
visual_concept: You promised to meet a friend. An emergency requires you elsewhere. Two real obligations pointing opposite ways - logical conflict?
